properties.sfomuseum:description: Interview conducted by Carol McLaughlin on May 19 and 20, 2004Final transcriptThe interview describes the life and career of Zoe Dell Nutter, who worked as a promotional “theme girl,” and later official hostess, for the 1939 Golden Gate International Exposition (GGIE, or World’s Fair). She describes her promotional work, the flights she took on Douglas DC-3 aircraft, and the aviation leaders, airlines, and dignitaries she made contact with during that time; descriptions of Mills Field and Treasure Island; development of the GGIE, the events, and her local and cross-country promotional work. She discusses the effects of World War II on the GGIE, the work she performed after the closure of the GGIE in 1940; her marriage and home life; her experiences on a prototype version of the Douglas DC-4 around 1942; training as a private pilot on Piper aircraft; ongoing licensing during her lifetime; her work as the California representative to the Brussels Expo ’58 and the Seattle World’s Fair, as well as her flights on Pan American World Airways at that time; her work as a salesperson and trainer for Piper Aircraft in Monterey, California beginning in 1962, and her experiences flying cross-country flight in a Piper trainer aircraft around that time; organizing a chapter of the Ninety-Nines in Dayton, Ohio, significance of the organization; her work with the Aviation Hall of Fame and serving as the first female president; thoughts on the importance of Dayton to the Wright brothers; her work with the San Francisco Aeronautical Society; encounters with Edward Rickenbacker, Fiorello La Guardia, Douglas (“Wrong-way”) Corrigan, Paul Mantz [stunt pilot], William Randolph Hearst, Leland W. Cutler, Charles H. “Doc” Strub (Board of GGIE Trustees), James S. McDonnell, William Patterson, and Juan Trippe.
